did.unittitle: South Asian Pamphlets collection 1920-2005 (bulk 1950-2000)
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The South Asian Pamphlets Collection spans the years 1920-2005, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1950s to the 1990s, and with only a few items from the 1920s-1940s. It is arranged in the following categories by country of publication: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. The largest group houses publications from India (177 boxes), followed by Pakistan (58 boxes). Topics commonly covered in each country series include but are not limited to agriculture, arts, defense, economic development, education, ethnic or cultural conflict, industry and commerce, international relations, politics and government, population issues, religion and philosophy, rural development, tourism, and the status of women. While the majority of the pamphlets were published by organizations and agencies and do not list individual authors' names, there are also pamphlets with individual authors listed.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The publications in the South Asian Pamphlets Collection were received by Duke University's Perkins Library over four decades, roughly from 1960-1990, through the Library of Congress South Asia Cooperative Acquisition Program (SACAP), formerly called the "PL-480 Program."

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and inventoried by Sana Ahmed, Ricardo Javier Huamán, Shefali Mathur, Aditi Misra, and Simrat Wason, October 2008
Encoded by Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, June 2009
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The South Asian Pamphlets Collection spans the years 1920-2005, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1950s to the 1990s, and with only a few items from the 1920s-1940s. The publications were received by Duke University's Perkins Library over four decades, roughly from 1960-1990, through the Library of Congress South Asia Cooperative Acquisition Program (SACAP), formerly called the "PL-480 Program," and are arranged according to their country of publication: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. The pamphlets are all published in the English language. The largest group houses publications from India (177 boxes), followed by Pakistan (58 boxes), Bangladesh (15 boxes), and Nepal (8 boxes). For the smallest groupings of Afghanistan and Sri Lanka, the pamphlets are organized alphabetically by title without any further subdivisions. For the larger country series, the pamphlets are arranged by topical headings, in alphabetical order, and within, alphabetically by title. Each country series is followed by a more detailed description of its contents; each topical division is also followed by a description which includes the number of boxes and number of items in that subdivision.

While the majority of the pamphlets were published by organizations and agencies and do not list individual authors' names, there are also pamphlets with individual authors listed. Topical divisions common to the larger country series include but are not limited to Agriculture, Arts, Economic Development, Education, Industry and Commerce, International Relations, Politics and Government, Religion and Philosophy, Rural Development, Tourism, and Women. Many of the publications across the entire collection discuss ethnic and political conflict, as well as the effects of wars, poverty, and mass education, and issues regarding Islam and other religious traditions. Particular countries may have unique topical headings. In the case of India, each major Indian political party has its own subdivision under the larger Political Parties series; there is also a section for biographical works, and one for works on libraries and museums, and a division was also established to house pamphlets related to Kashmir.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. Where there is no information on place of publication, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information. For more information on each country and its subdivisions, see the listings that follow.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for each country division in this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

item.geogname: Sri Lanka -- Politics and government -- 20th century

did.unittitle: Afghanistan Pamphlets, 1970s-1993

scopecontent.p: These 19 pamphlets were published by Afghan individuals and institutional offices in exile in Pakistan during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. Topics covered include the status of Afghan refugees; Pakistan's foreign policy; U.N. resolutions; country reports; the Soviet occupation and war in Afghanistan; foreign aid; armed responses to the Soviet aggressions; and the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan. Publications include official decrees of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan, a gazetteer, and news reports from Afghani and foreign media.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.

Bangladesh Pamphlets, 1957-2002

scopecontent.p: Publications are subdivided into the following groupings, described fully below each heading: Agriculture, Arts, Economics and Public Policy, Education, Industry and Commerce, International Relations, Law, Miscellaneous Subjects, Politics and Government, Population and Birth Control, Rural Development, and Tourism.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.

India Pamphlets, 1920-2005, bulk 1960-1990

scopecontent.p: This series constitutes the majority of the entire South Asia Pamphlet Collection. A diverse mix of propaganda and scholarly articles, essays, and other publications, these pamphlets reflect some of the major events of the period between the 1960s and 1990s, such as the political instability in the post-Nehru era, India-Pakistan wars of 1965 and 1971 (the latter resulting in the break up of Pakistan and emergence of Bangladesh as a nation); the imposition of national emergency by the Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1975; the Punjab crisis (Sikh separatist movement for an autonomous homeland); military action by Mrs. Gandhi on the Golden Temple to eject militant Sikhs; and her revenge assassination by one of her Sikh bodyguards. This period also witnessed widespread food shortages; controversial forced sterilizations; ethnic riots following the death of Mrs. Gandhi; the rise of Hindu right nationalist movement; demolition of the Babari Masjid; communal riots between Hindus and Muslims; and nuclear underground tests by India. In addition, the pamphlets offer information on the many cultural legacies and changes present during the same period in arts and literature.

Most of the material was published by central and regional governmental agencies. Other sources include political parties, non-governmental organizations, and individual authors. Among the political party publications the largest number is from the Communist Party of India (Marxist), followed by the All-India National Congress and its various factions, then the Bharatiya Janata Party, Swatantra Party, and labor organizations. Some of the prominent authors from various political parties and economists include: L. K. Advani, Jyoti Basu, N. Dandekar, G. R. Gadgil, Rammanohar Lohia, M. R. Masani, K. Santhanam, S. G. Sardesai, Manmohan Singh, and George Fernances. (More works by these authors can be found in the Duke University Library's online catalog.)

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.

arrangement.p: The pamphlets are arranged into these subseries, listed alphabetically: Agriculture; Anthropology and Sociology; Arts; Civil Service; Communal Violence and Ethnic Conflict; Cooperative Movements; Dams; Defense; Disasters; Economics (a large series divided further into subseries); Elections; Employment; Energy; Environment and Forestry; Health Care; History and Culture; Human Rights; International and Area Studies; International Commerce; International Economic Relations; International Relations; Labor and Working Conditions; Language and Literature; Law and Legislation; Law and Order; Libraries and Museums; Mass Communication; Minorities; Performing Arts; Political Parties (a large series subdivided into groupings by party); Politics and Government; Population and Birth Control; Posters; Public Policy and Social Welfare; Religion and Philosophy; Rural Development; Science; Sports; Tourism; Transportation; Urban Planning; Water Resources; Wildlife; Women's Studies; and Youth, India. Each of these sections is further described below with the number of boxes and the types of topics covered by the material. Within each subdivision, pamphlets are arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.p: The 13 pamphlets in this group were published chiefly by institutions and government agencies, with some by individual authors; they cover a variety of topics in anthropology and sociology as disciplines and professions. A few publications speak of Indian society and issues such as caste systems. There are no works on archaeological sites or anthropogical discoveries.

Handicrafts

scopecontent.p: The 57 pamphlets in the Arts and Handicrafts section were published by official government agencies and individuals between 1964 and 1987. These pamphlets provide information on decorative designs; textiles; embroidery; wood work; carving; terracotta; weaving; Khadi (handloom industry); papier mâché; metalware; and national awards to outstanding master craftsmen, including biographies and citations. Tribal arts and crafts from various regions of India by individual craftsmen as well as work sponsored by federal and state government agencies are represented.

Biography, 1962-1989

scopecontent.p: The 100 pamphlets in this section chiefly consist of biographical sketches or essays on politicians, statesmen, national leaders, Indian freedom fighters abroad, patriots and religious leaders. There are various publications featuring Mahatma Gandhi, including a desk diary with numerous photographs released on his birth centenary in 1969. Each page of the desk diary contains quotes from Gandhi in both English and Hindi.

Communal Violence and Ethnic Conflict, 1948-1990

scopecontent.p: With a focus on violence and ethnic conflict, the 46 pamphlets in this section were published by NGOs, political parties, government agencies and individuals. They pamphlets contain commentary on violence by independent secular groups; appeals by community leaders against violence; reports of inquiries; details on inter-community relations between various religious groups; and analyses of riots in Indian cities such as Meerut, Bombay, Assam, Bhiwandi, Bhopal and Jamshedpur. Coverage is given to Babri Masjid, the Ram Janam Bhoomi controversy and the Gujarat massacre.

did.unittitle: Economics, 1957-1990s

scopecontent.p: The 379 pamphlets in the Economics series cover a wide range of issues and are arranged in two divisions: Economic Development and Economic Policy. The publications in Economic Policy are further subdivided into three groupings: general issues (the largest section by far, with 261 pamphlets); central government planning; and regional economic policies and efforts. Further descriptions follow below.

Economic Policy, 1957-1990s

scopecontent.p: Pamphlets related to the central government's five-year plans were published by the Planning Commission of the Government of India. Others were published by NGOs and political parties. The pamphlets were published between the 1960s and the 1990s. These 29 pamphlets provide information on official economic policy through successive five-year plans and analyses and critiques of various five-year plans. A few pamphlets have charts or graphs and pictorial presentations.

did.unittitle: Education, 1927-1990

scopecontent.p: Publications in this category cover a wide range of issues in education in India, including: curriculum formation and syllabi; education planning; illiteracy; teacher training; universities and colleges; rural education; testing; adult education programs; and educational reform. Pamphlets also discuss specific areas in education such as law, agricultural training, religion, physical education, and science, to which an entire subgrouping is devoted. The main subgroupings with further descriptions below are General Education; Adult Education; Higher Education; Science Education; Syllabi; Teacher Training; and Vocational Education. The two largest sections are General Education, with 139 publications, and Higher Education, with 117.

did.unittitle: General, 1960-1990

scopecontent.p: The 139 pamphlets in this section were published by government agencies, universities, educational associations and individuals. They provide information on after school programs, education planning, educational reform, the role of students, reports initiated by the University Grants Commission, the role of education in development, religious education, statistical reviews, physical education, examination reforms, scholarships and educational loans and student and teachers' associations.

Industry, 1960-1990

scopecontent.p: Divided into two sections, General Industry and Small-Scale Industry, described fully below.

did.unittitle: General Industry, 1961-1990

scopecontent.p: The 142 pamphlets in this section were published by official government agencies, private institutes, corporations and individuals from the 1960s to the 1990s. They provide information on research and development in industry; working conditions; heavy and medium to large size industries; the development of industrial towns; companies such as Bhilai and Tatas; the steel industry; textiles; chemicals; industrial training and education; industrial finance; engineering; federal and state industrial policies; promotional information; and industry in the public and private sectors. There are also 25 publications by the Indian Standards Institution on the Sectional List of Indian Standards.

scopecontent.p: The 149 pamphlets in this section were published by government agencies, political parties and NGOs. They contain information on foreign relations; independent appraisals of the political systems of various countries; and policy statements - mostly by leftist political parties - on India's relations with various countries. Topics include peace efforts relating to disarmament; India's emergence as a nuclear power; non-alignment; human rights; the Cold War; the state visits of Indian and foreign leaders; international friendship organizations; and the Tashkent declaration.

Kashmir Question, 1959-2005

scopecontent.p: The 36 pamphlets in this section were published by official government agencies and NGOs. Some pamphlets articulate arguments by Indian nationalists, mostly Hindus, making a case for Kashmir to stay in India. Other topics include the historical background on Pakistani aggression in Kashmir, the viewpoints of various political parties, the issue of autonomy, and the policies of the Government of Jammu and Kashmir. Some maps of areas in question are also found here.

Labor and Working Conditions, 1961-1990

scopecontent.p: The 158 pamphlets in this section were published by official government agencies, NGOs and political parties. They touch on a wide variety of topics relating to working conditions: labor conditions in various industries; training; child labor; strikes and the right to strike; the constitutions and rules and regulations of various trade unions; directories of trade union leaders; discipline; domestic inquiries; collective bargaining; intervention rivalries; All India Kisan Sabha; Hind Mazdoor Sabha; Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh; the Center for Indian Trade Unions; job statistics; and work benefits. Law and Legislation, 1920-1990

scopecontent.p: The 35 pamphlets in this section were published by official government agencies, NGOs and individuals. They chiefly contain conference proceedings, civil procedures, essays about the constitution and judiciary, legislation on various subjects, acts relating to university charters, and legislation concerning the public right to know. Other topics include the Dowry Legislation, civil rights, the Wakf administration, rules governing behavior of judges and lawyers, the National Security Act, civil code and parliamentary practice and procedures, the law of preventive detention, the freedom of speech, criminal law, and the teaching of law.

The 68 pamphlets in this section were published primarily by the All India Congress Committee between 1961 and 1986. These pamphlets provide information on resolutions on party policies, international relations, planning, education, industry, manifestos, election propaganda, by-laws, minutes of AICC meetings, presidential addresses and agricultural and land reform.

did.unittitle: Politics and Government, 1928-1991

scopecontent.p: The 260 pamphlets in this large section were published by official government agencies, NGOs, political parties and individuals. They discuss such topics as economic development, administration, corruption in government, the Punjab problem, affirmative action, uplift of economically disadvantaged classes, the Punjab/Khalistan issue, political alliances among the various parties, civil service, views by extremist groups, center-state relations, and the Naxalite and the Telengana struggle. Formats include conference proceedings, lectures by various political personalities, and speeches and addresses by members of legislatures and governors.

Religion and Philosophy, 1950-2000

scopecontent.p: The 181 pamphlets in this large grouping were published by the Henry Martin Institute of Islamic Studies, the All India Muslim Educational Society, the Gandhi Peace Foundation, the Institute of Social Sciences, Aurobindo Ashram, and other religious groups and individuals between 1950 and 2000. Formats range from pamphlets to descriptions of places of pilgrimage. They cover a wide range of topics: missionary activity among tribals; the issue of cow slaughter; religious shrines; religious polemics; various sects in Hinduism and their founders; religious institutions; social responsibility of religious leaders; modern religious movements such as Ayra Samaj and Rama Krishna; the issue of untouchability; religious and ethical questions; religion and science; universal brotherhood; and the founders of various religions, Sikhism, Buddhism, Islam, Christianity and Jainism.

Rural Development, 1961-1990

scopecontent.p: Published by federal and state governments, political parties, NGOs, universities and individuals, the 77 pamphlets in this section provide information on community development programs, problems of landless labor, rural poverty, unemployment, agriculture, the training of rural workers, agriculture and social forestry, housing and education. There are also about 15 pamphlets in this section that provide information on the Panchayat, assembly (yat) of five (panch) wise and respected elders chosen and accepted by the village community, and Nyaya Panchayat (a system of dispute resolution at village level in India) in various parts of the country.

Science, 1961-1991

scopecontent.p: The 68 pamphlets in this section were published by government agencies, scientific associations, and political parties. They provide information on science and technology; the atomic and nuclear industries; medicine; scientific societies; scientific explorations; training institutes; meteorology; geography; space exploration; engineering; medical research; satellite technology (INSAT); mining; remote sensing; medical research; medical science; and international conferences. Publications include reports by the Indian National Science Academy and the Council of Scientific and Industry Research, as well as publications from the Indian Standards Institute.

Nepal Pamphlets, 1960s-1998

scopecontent.p: Publications produced by Nepalese government agencies and individuals, or private institutions, covering a wide range of topics. Subdivided into the following categories, described below: Agriculture and Rural Development; Biography; Commerce and Industry; International Relations; Miscellaneous; Politics and Government; and Tourism, the largest of the series.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.

scopecontent.p: Printed materials for this large country group are arranged into the following subseries, described fully below: Agriculture, Arts (divided into Fine Arts and Handicrafts), Biography, Commerce, Education, Economics, Energy and Natural Resources, Health, Industry, International Relations, Kashmir Question, Labor, Language and Literature, Law, Libraries, Mass Communication, Performing Arts, Politics and Government - the largest series, Population and Birth Control, Religion and Philosophy, Rural Conditions, Science and Technology, Social Welfare, Tourism, Transportation, Urban Planning, Water Resources and Irrigation, and Women's Studies.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.

Women in Pakistan, 1967-1992

scopecontent.p: The 43 pamphlets in this section discuss women's education and training, violence against women, the status of women in Islam, Muslim Family Law, women in various professions, women in politics, women's health and employment, laws relating to women, and issues concerning prostitution. There is also a pamphlet on Muslim girls in the United States. Includes publications of the Women's Division of the Government of Pakistan, reports from the National Conference of Muslim Women, held in Pakistan, and eleven newsletters published by the All Pakistan Women's Association from 1960-1970.

Sri Lanka Pamphlets, 1950-1988

scopecontent.p: The 58 pamphlets in this section were published by official government agencies, private institutes and individuals. Topics areas include Sinhalese language and literature, biographies, ethnic tensions and violence, rural development, religion and philosophy, economic plans, politics and government, trade unions, the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, agriculture, religious shrines, archaeology, energy, industry, law and legal education, and dams.

For undated pamphlets, every effort was made to establish an approximate year or decade of publication; this is indicated by a question mark following the date. In cases where there is no place of publication information, the notation [n.p.] is used. In some cases there is a descriptive note below the entry that adds information about the item such as publication data, commemorative headings, inscriptions, and other contextual information.
